question: When should you yield the right-of-way to pedestrians?
option2: B) At all times, regardless of whether or not they are at a crosswalk
option3: C) Only if they are crossing in front of your vehicle
option4: D) Only when pedestrians are not jaywalking
correct_answer: B) At all times, regardless of whether or not they are at a crosswalk
explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians at all times, even if they are not in a crosswalk.

question: Who has the right-of-way when you are turning left at an intersection?
option1: A) Vehicles approaching from the left
option2: B) Vehicles approaching from the right
explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to vehicles coming from the opposite direction, pedestrians in the crosswalk, and any other traffic at the intersection.

question: What should you do when you approach an intersection and a vehicle is already there, but you have a stop sign?
option1: A) Proceed if you are not in their way
option2: B) Wait for them to go first if they are on the same road
option3: C) Go if they are turning
option4: D) Immediately go ahead of them
correct_answer: B) Wait for them to go first if they are on the same road
explanation: If another vehicle has arrived at the intersection first, you must wait for them to go first, even if you have a stop sign.

question: Who has the right-of-way when you are entering a roundabout?
option1: A) Vehicles already in the roundabout
option4: D) You, because you are already in the intersection
correct_answer: A) Vehicles already in the roundabout
explanation: Vehicles already in the roundabout have the right-of-way. You must yield to them before entering the roundabout.

question: What should you do if two vehicles approach an intersection at the same time and you are on the left?
option1: A) Yield to the vehicle on the right
option2: B) Proceed if the other vehicle is not moving
correct_answer: A) Yield to the vehicle on the right
explanation: When two vehicles approach an intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way.

question: At an uncontrolled intersection, who has the right-of-way?
option1: A) The vehicle on the right
option2: B) The vehicle on the left
option4: D) There is no rule; it's a free-for-all
correct_answer: A) The vehicle on the right
explanation: At an uncontrolled intersection (without signs or signals), the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way.

question: What should you do when you see a yield sign?
option1: A) Stop and wait for other vehicles to clear
option2: B) Slow down and yield to any traffic or pedestrians
option3: C) Continue driving at the same speed
option4: D) Speed up to avoid delay
correct_answer: B) Slow down and yield to any traffic or pedestrians
explanation: When you see a yield sign, you must slow down, be prepared to stop, and yield to any traffic or pedestrians that have the right-of-way.

question: What do you do if another driver is signaling to turn into your lane, and you are already in that lane?
option1: A) Speed up and cut them off
option2: B) Yield to the other driver and allow them to enter your lane
option3: C) Change lanes immediately to avoid them
correct_answer: B) Yield to the other driver and allow them to enter your lane
explanation: When another driver signals to turn into your lane, you must yield and allow them to enter safely.

question: Who has the right-of-way when merging onto a highway?
option1: A) The vehicle merging onto the highway
option2: B) The vehicles already on the highway
option3: C) Both vehicles have equal rights
option4: D) The vehicle with the fastest speed
correct_answer: B) The vehicles already on the highway
explanation: Vehicles already on the highway have the right-of-way when another vehicle merges onto it.
